dataIdInfo.idPurp: This is the wrapped interferogram for a pair of Sentinel-1 SLC granules, processed using GAMMA software. The fringes represent phase difference values on a wrapped 2-pi scale, with pixel values ranging from negative pi to pi. It is a 32-bit float GeoTIFF projected to WGS 84 / UTM zone 27N, and has a pixel spacing of 80 m. It was processed from the SLC using 20x4 looks (20 looks in the range direction and 4 looks in the azimuth direction).
dataIdInfo.idAbs:
This is the wrapped interferogram for a pair of Sentinel-1 SLC granules, processed using GAMMA software. The pixel values indicate the wrapped phase difference values (on a 2-pi scale) of the interferogram prior to unwrapping. The file is a 32-bit float GeoTIFF projected to WGS 84 / UTM zone 27N, and has a pixel spacing of 80 m. It was processed from the SLC using 20x4 looks (20 looks in the range direction and 4 looks in the azimuth direction).

Reference Scene: S1A_IW_SLC__1SDV_20210313T075846_20210313T075901_036977_0459C8_D473

Secondary Scene: S1A_IW_SLC__1SDV_20210325T075846_20210325T075901_037152_045FD0_A429

Processing Date/Time: 2022-12-08T12:50:35+00:00

Because the values are on a wrapped 2-pi scale rather than representing continuous phase difference values, a wrapped interferogram tends to be most useful as a color visualization. Each fringe (one cycle through the color ramp) indicates line-of-sight displacement equivalent to half the sensor wavelength. The Sentinel-1 SAR sensor has a wavelength of 5.6 cm, so each fringe would represent a line-of-sight displacement of 2.8 cm. Fringes that are very close together indicate greater amounts of deformation than wider fringes.

A browse image, tagged with color_phase.png, is also included in the product package. It is a resampled medium-resolution version of this dataset with the backscatter intensity incorporated in the background to give topographic context to the displacement. The fringes have a pre-set color ramp applied, which can make them easier to count than in a black-and-white rendering, but the amplitude background and lower resolution of the browse can make fringes difficult to distinguish in areas of high deformation.

No atmospheric corrections have been applied to this interferogram. Use caution when looking at a single interferogram, as atmospheric effects can easily be misinterpreted as surface deformation. While SAR signals can penetrate clouds, atmospheric conditions can delay the transmission of the signal. This results in phase differences that can look like surface deformation signals, but are actually driven by differences in the atmospheric conditions between the pair of acquisitions used to generate the interferogram. Consider applying an atmospheric model to correct for atmospheric delay, or examining other InSAR pairs that bracket the same event but were acquired on different dates to determine if atmospheric effects are driving the phase differences.

To view this GeoTIFF in ArcGIS with a color ramp similar to the one applied to the browse, open the symbology properties for the layer (or click on the color ramp in the TOC) and apply a color ramp that utilizes a wide range of the spectrum. For ArcGIS Pro, the Bathymetry color ramp in inverse order most closely replicates the GAMMA color ramp, but the Spectral (Continuous) color ramp also works well. In ArcMap, the Spectrum-Full Bright color ramp works well.

Refer to ASF's InSAR Product Guide for more information about On Demand InSAR products.

The Sentinel-1 mission is designed to be a two-satellite constellation. Sentinel-1A was launched April 3, 2014, and remains active. Sentinel-1B was launched April 25, 2016, and was active until December 23, 2021. The satellites each have a 12-day repeat cycle and use the same orbit pattern, but are offset 180 degrees to allow repeat passes every 6 days while both are active.

Since the mission ended for S1B, there are some significant gaps in coverage. A reduced acquisition plan will be in place until Sentinel-1C is launched (expected in 2023) to replace Sentinel-1B. Visit https://hyp3-docs.asf.alaska.edu/sentinel1 for more information.

More information about the Sentinel-1 mission is available at https://sentinels.copernicus.eu/web/sentinel/missions/sentinel-1.

Additional information about Sentinel-1 data, imagery, tools and applications is available at https://asf.alaska.edu/data-sets/sar-data-sets/sentinel-1.
dataIdInfo.idCredit:
When using this data as an image in a publication such as journal papers, articles, presentations, posters, and websites, please include the following credit with the image (portions in square brackets are optional):
[InSAR product processed by ]ASF DAAC HyP3 2022[ using GAMMA software]. Contains modified Copernicus Sentinel data 2021, processed by ESA.
When using this data in a manuscript and/or crediting datasets used for analysis, an acknowledgement including the software versions may be appropriate:
ASF DAAC HyP3 2022 using the hyp3_gamma plugin version 5.7.1 running GAMMA release 20220630. Contains modified Copernicus Sentinel data 2021, processed by ESA.
For more information on citing the dataset, please refer to the README file distributed with this product.

Consts.useLimit: There are no restrictions on the use of this data, but it must be acknowledged or cited as listed in the credits.

dataIdInfo.envirDesc: This product was generated by ASF DAAC HyP3 2022 using the hyp3_gamma plugin version 5.7.1 running GAMMA release 20220630.

dataLineage.statement:
The wrapped phase interferogram is generated prior to the phase unwrapping step (step 8) during InSAR processing.
The basic steps in InSAR processing are as follows:
*Pre-Processing* 1. Ingest SLC data into GAMMA format 2. Get DEM file covering the area, apply geoid correction and resample/reproject as required 3. Calculate overlapping bursts for input scenes 4. Mosaic swaths and bursts together
*InSAR Processing* 5. Prepare initial look-up table and simulated unwrapped image - Derive lookup table for SLC/MLI co-registration (considering terrain heights) - Simulate unwrapped interferometric phase using DEM height, and deformation rate using orbit state vectors 6. Interferogram creation, matching, refinement - Initial co-registration with look-up table - Iterative co-registration with look-up table - Removal of curved earth and topographic phase 7. Determine a co-registration offset based on the burst overlap (spectral diversity method) - Single iteration co-registration with look-up table 8. Phase unwrapping and coherence map generation 9. Generation of displacement maps from unwrapped differential phase
*Post-Processing* 10. Generation of geocoded GeoTIFF outputs
For a detailed description of InSAR processing using GAMMA software, refer to the readme file included with the product package.
